@xinyuiscool @sborya @prateekm 
Please take a look when you get a chance.
QQ: How much time is 50 retries here?

@prateekm 
50 retries is approximately equal to 83 mins retries in time(initialDelay=`100 ms`, backoffMultiplier=`2`).

For some critical jobs, its required that unavailability of broker for an hour or so should not bring their job down(which will require fail-over to a backup colo).

If required we can reduce this retry duration.

@shanthoosh That's fine, just add a comment next to the constant 50 that this is ~ 83 min.
Otherwise LGTM.
@prateekm committed changes from your most recent suggestions. Thanks!
@prateekm added changes regarding your comments.
Thanks for helping review! @nickpan47 please take a look when you get the chance.

@xinyuiscool Can you provide some motivation for this new feature? My original intention was to let users get callbacks on a fixed container wide timer interval, similar to the behavior of WindowableTask. This feature seems a lot more general. Also, I'd prefer to not introduce a new context object/mechanism right now since @nickpan47 is working on cleaning up that part of the API.

@prateekm : there are two main motivations behind:
- For BEAM to support processing time timer/trigger, this is a MUST. I need the capability of registering arbitrary timers anytime during processing. For example, for BEAM's trigger:
AfterProcessingTime
        .pastFirstElementInPane()
        .plusDelayOf(Duration.standardMinutes(5)
This requires registering the trigger after first element shows up in the window pane. On the BEAM side, I am waiting eagerly for this feature to be added so I can push the code.

- For Samza, this allows the better windowing and trigger. It allows each window to register a different timer, instead of using the GCD hack we currently do (this fix is also requested by @cpettitt-linkedin ). It also allows the time trigger to use a real system timer, instead of approximating it by using the time of incoming message. I believe with this patch it will be straightforward to improve both existing features.

I think adding the context on the Operator level is inevitable to support timer on the operator level. This should also be needed if we need more context object on the operator level. I can talk to @nickpan47 about this, but I don't think the future refactoring should block current feature development.

@xinyuiscool Makes sense to implement if this is required for BEAM. If we're adding it to the Samza public API, that's fine too - its certainly a more flexible behavior than the current window implementation. Good point about timer triggers as well. If we do that, we should update and clarify the existing documentation, both javadoc and the introduction/architecture pages.

Re: adding the OpContext, not sure I understand why that is required if we can register the timers on the TaskContext directly. Let me take a look at the code again. Agree that refactoring shouldn't block feature development, but we also shouldn't add/change public APIs that may get refactored again. Let's check with @nickpan47 what the timeline looks like.

If you agree, we can have a follow up PR to this, where we will have  bounded wait time in LocalApplicationRunner.waitForFinish API as well.
@jwlent55 : thanks a lot for this patch. I need some time to think through about this chance. Please bear with me for a few days. Thanks.

I appreciate your interest in this issue and realize it may take time to evaluate.  There may well be other and better ways to address this issue.  I took a minimalist approach which I hoped would reduce the chance of actually making things worse.  

I briefly considered a more aggressive approach. My thought was to make each thread have its own main loop (and get rid of ThreadJob) and permanently assign each thread one or more partitions to work with.  Basically simulate the individual JVM approach with threads.  Each thread would round robin among the assigned partitions, but, there would be no notion of fairness between threads.  The JVM would do the load sharing between threads much as the OS controlled load sharing between multiple JVMs (each with there own set of partitions) for the single threaded approach.

I also considered relaxing the notion of fairness between threads by keeping the Chooser full (calling tryUpdate as soon as the previous message was inserted).

Both those ideas sounded more like features than bug fixes and would require extensive design, review, and testing. I therefore did not pursue them, but, it would not surprise me if you suggested something equally different from what I have coded up.
Is there a JIRA that tracks this? If not, consider creating one and linking it here? It will be helpful for others who don't have as much context.
@nickpan47 @jmakes Can we merge this patch for the next release?

@sborya @xinyuiscool  
Please take a look when you get a chance.
Please ignore the outdated comments. Agree with @sborya that the previous version was making the shutdown sequence very complex.
@shanthoosh For clarity, I'd recommend that we conclude the discussion on the SEP (including iterating on feedback) before submitting PR. I don't recall seeing a final VOTE.
@jmakes can we close this PR?
@shanthoosh please update ticket and PR title.
@shanthoosh Please update ticket and PR title.
@prateekm it was never approved. Do you have more feedback?

Sorry that it took so long. Thanks a lot for this patch. As you already analyzed very thoroughly, this is a flaw in current AsyncRunLoop that relies on the poll timeout to avoid busy loop, which caused long delays for tasks which have already completed processing. The way of your fix makes sense to me: AsyncRunLoop should use the latch to wait instead of relying on poll timeout.This will allow the other tasks to proceed. Nice work!

For the fix implementation, I notice two things:

1) Did you also configure task.poll.interval.ms to be 0 in order to get rid of the poll waiting? Seems to me it's a must since otherwise the run loop will still poll quite often in case of empty partitions. To this point, looks like we don't need the poll timeout (task.poll.inverval.ms) anymore after this change, since runloop will control the poll interval, and we should immediately return after systemconsumers.poll() in any case. If this is the case, would you mind also make SystemConsumers.poll() always return without waiting?

2) seems the logic of blockIfNoWork() can be moved into blockIfBusy(), basically doing the same check of null envelope and wait if no worker is available. Is that something feasible?

Thanks!

Regarding your questions: 

1) I agree the timeout should never be set to 0. Not sure it should even be configurable. I did so really for testing purposes (so I could modify it without rebuilding my application). I suppose someone might want to tweak it to trade CPU for latency, but, I would be OK with not even making it configurable. The 10 ms value I based it on was not. 

2) I do like the idea of having only one check. Originally I thought that the blockIfNoWork needed to come before the runTasks call, but, that was most likely before I found some race conditions and decided to add the (admittedly somewhat ugly) runLoopResumedSinceLastChecked boolean. Now I think it could be after and therefore the two checks could be combined. That will require a bit of testing (and thought). One other option I originally considered, but, dismissed as a bit risky was to remove the blockIfBusy check. The idea being that eventually if all the task were busy the Chooser would stop finding work and the new check would force a pause. I could not convince myself I understood the code well enough to guarantee that in all cases.

@jwlent55 : I think you might misunderstood my first question. Now we have two waits here: one for the poll (task.poll.interval.ms), and the other for no work (task.max.no.work.wait.ms). My question is that since we can now use the second wait to control the polling (if there is no work, don't poll until task.max.no.work.wait.ms), seems we don't need the first wait anymore (equal to set task.poll.interval.ms=0). The AsyncRunLoop was relying on the first poll timer to avoid busy looping, but now it should be fine to return immediately after polling any SystemConsumer. This seems to be the goal we want to achieve here: AsyncRunLoop will control the polling by knowing whether there is worker available to process the message. And this should be much more efficient as you experiments demonstrated. What do you think?

You are correct.  I completely misread your first question.  Without looking at the code I mistook it for a question I already had in my mind and went off into the weeds.  Let me try again.

I did not set the task.poll.interval.ms to 0 (which is used to set "pollIntervalMs").  I left it at its default 50 ms.  I think it is still necessary to ensure that if some partitions have exhausted the their "unprocessedMessagesBySSP", but, others are keeping up with main loop Chooser (so that it always finds new work to process) that the main loop will still occasionally (every 50 ms) check to see if the currently empty partitions have new messages to "drain" from the bufferedMessages queue.  This call should not block if the "timeout" variable is set to zero (when it is 0 this "poll" is really just a "drainTo").  My proposed update includes logic to ensure that timeout value is always set to 0 if we are not planning to update the Chooser during the call to choose (i.e., in the AsyncRunLoop case).  I think this same logic stops the blocking/polling both in the "no work" case and in the "long time (50 ms) since last poll" case.

On a related note when I first started working on this issue I thought the problem might be in the 
BlockingEnvelopeMap.poll method.  I noted that it would block on the first SSP that did not have any messages (if the timeout was greater than zero) even if other empty partitions had messages ready to "drain".  I reorganized the logic so it first "drained" all the queues and only then if it could not find at least one message to process start "polling" the SSPs one by one (and most likely blocking on the first one). That did not address my issue so I did not include that logic in my change.

While investigating your question I noted that I had not included documentation for my new parameter in the configuration-table.html file.  I assume I should do so.  Let me know if you want this new parameter left out.
I have gone ahead and made a first pass at addressing your code inspection comments.  Happy to make more changes.

@xinyuiscool Please take a look when you get a chance.

Deletes the ephemeral node  in clean shutdown flow.

Not sure about this failure.  Looks like a networking issue.  The testClearStream passes for me locally.

```
$ ./gradlew clean check

:samza-kafka_2.11:testClasses
:samza-kafka_2.11:test

```
Is there a way for me to retry the test?

As for the suggestion:

  "would you mind also make SystemConsumers.poll() always return without waiting"

I think I have made it never block when it is called (indirectly) from AsyncRunLoop (by ensuring timeout = 0 when it calls ), but, I think it still needs the ability to block when it is called (indirectly) from RunLoop (where timeout may be equal to 10).  Maybe I misunderstand this comment.

Now that I take a second look at the timeout setting code I think I need to make setting it to 0 more explicit.  I will make another update.  On the plus side this change should trigger another build.  Maybe that will clear the error.

I am a bit busy for the next couple of days and may no have time much time to spend on this issue.  Also I have not yet had time to work on combining the blockIfNoWork() and blockIfBusy() code.

@jwlent55 : your update makes a lot of sense to me (and clears the error too :) )! Runloop is actually deprecated (I didn't get a chance to finally remove that class, we have a ticket to track it), so this poll will only be made from AsyncRunLoop. Seems to me we don't need the poll timer anymore after your change. If that's out of scope for this patch, I can put it under the ticket of removing RunLoop so it will be cleaned up.

No hurry on the combining the block() methods. I believe it will work pretty well afterwards (need your help to test with your test jobs). Thanks a lot for being very thorough on this issue and make our runloop much more efficient.
@jmakes and @prateekm , Dong has finished the revision and this patch is ready to be committed. Are you guys still -1 on this patch? Could you quickly check and respond? Thanks!
@vjagadish1989 @jmakes

Wei can probably weigh in. But I remember skipBadMessage is not just about large message. It's about some schema issue with Gobblin as well. So what is our design here? Will that be addressed separated in LI code?
@PawasChhokra Does this still need to be merged? If not, can we close this PR?
@lindong28 Does this still need to be reviewed/merged? If not, can you close this PR?
@jmakes Does this still need to be reviewed/merged?
@prateekm Sure, I closed the PR now.
@prateekm Yes. I haven't pressed it because there is a tools bug in LI preventing us from adopting it. But it's very much needed.

My apologies for the bogus call to containerMetrics that I accidentally left in the code when I combined the block and delay code and moved them both to before run.  The reason I chose that location was because in the delay case it makes sense to call run next.  Choose will most likely not return anything again until run has been called (unless the 50 ms poll interval has been reached).  I think the code will work in either location so if you prefer the previous order better (choose/run/block-delay) let me know.

@lhaiesp Right now the only bad message that we skip is large message so the skipBadMessage datastream config will be converted into skipLargeMesage right now. In future skipBadMesage datastream config can be converted into any other config that we may add in future. Discussed the above behavior with @weisong44 and he is fine with it.

@jwlent55 : The changes look great! Thanks a lot for this fix. 

Btw, did you get a chance to run a few cases in your benchmark after the code refactoring? It will be great to confirm the change didn't break anything. Thanks.
